<ul>
 <li> Atomic nucleus Related subjects Physics The nucleus of an atom is the very small dense region of an atom in its centre consisting of nucleons protons and neutrons The size diameter of the nucleus is in the range of 1 6 fm 10 -15 m for a<strong>  . . .</strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> atoms such as uranium These dimensions are much smaller than the size of the atom itself by a factor of about 23,000 uranium to about 145,000 hydrogen Almost all of the mass in an atom is made up from the protons and neutrons in the<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> a nut In 1844 Michael Faraday used the term to refer to the central point of an atom The modern atomic meaning was proposed by Ernest Rutherford in 1912 The adoption of the term nucleus to atomic theory however was not immediate In 1916 for<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> masses and their combined number the mass number is approximately equal to the atomic mass of an atom The combined mass of the electrons is very small in comparison to the mass of the nucleus since protons and neutrons weigh roughly 2000 times<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 </ul>

 <li><strong>. . . </strong> in each discrete molecule of that compound If a molecule contains more than one atom of a particular element this quantity is indicated using a subscript after the chemical symbol although 19th-century books often used superscripts For ionic<strong>  . . .</strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> structural formula For example methane a simple molecule consisting of one carbon atom bonded to four hydrogen atoms has the chemical formula CH 4 and glucose with six carbon atoms twelve hydrogen atoms and six oxygen atoms has the chemical<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> ethane consists of two carbon atoms single-bonded to each other with each carbon atom having three hydrogen atoms bonded to it Its chemical formula can be rendered as CH 3 CH 3 In ethylene there is a double bond between the carbon atoms and<strong>. . . </strong></li>
 <li><strong>. . . </strong> 18 O 16 O A left-hand subscript is sometimes used to indicate redundantly the atomic number For example 8 O 2 for dioxygen and 16 8 O 2 for the most abundant isotopic species of dioxygen This is convenient when writing equations for nuclear<strong>. . . </strong></li>
